data.text: Crank Arm Length of a Touring Bike

Question for the frame/crank length nerds in the group: my road bike has 170 size cranks and my recently purchased Trek 520, my first touring bike, has cranks of 175. The 520 frame is size 54 and my roadie is 52. Having only done a few rides of moderate length so far, the 520 feels great. I'm just wondering if I'm possibly setting myself up for potential knee injuries from the longer cranks, or if the relaxed frame geometry of the tourer somehow negates this. I suppose I'll know more once I can take the 520 out for longer rides, but if anyone has any experience or knowledge with this sort of thing I'd like to hear what you have to say. Happy riding!

In my opinion, it depends on your inseam length. I am a taller rider and found that 180 mm cranks are so much better for me than the default (mostly 175 mm) that comes on larger frames. The thing that can cause knee problems in my experience is having a seat that is either too high or too low.

data.text: Frame geometry cannot compensate for crank length: they are different measurements for different parts of your body. (If your shirt sleeves are too short, a longer shirt body doesn't help) Crank length determines two things: where your feet will be at the top of each pedal stroke, and where they will be at the bottom of each pedal stroke. Changing crank length by 5mm makes a 10mm difference to this distance between top and bottom, so it's a significant change (just as significant as a 10mm change in seat height). If you can't find a bike fitter that you trust, you'll need to rely on your own assessment and instinct, and YouTube can really help. I'm 180cm tall and ride 172.5mm cranks and that's perfect for me but as mentioned above it's your inside leg measurement that's the critical measurement here. Ultimately if you are comfortable on the bike, no joint ache or saddle soreness, you've got it right. If your knees or hips ache or you are getting rubbing on the saddle, it's time to re-consider your bike fit.

data.text: Crank arm length is a really big deal. I got a professional fit 20 years ago, was told to use 172.5mm cranks for my 30" inseam and I've never looked back. The jump from 170mm to 175mm is really big and one of those sizes is definitely the wrong one for you. What size is right for you depends on many factors so I'd do some research one weekend and see what bike fitters say. Save your knees!
data.author: Mike Schlacter

data.text: There is no wrong and no right when it comes to crank length. I personally prefer to have all cranks the same length, and if you have a long and extensive history of riding this generally is considered a good idea. If only ride a few thousand miles a year then there is no reason to assume you really have gotten used to a particular crank length and I wouldn't worry really.

data.text: Longer cranks are just one facet of gearing which controls stressing joints. Compare the total gear-inches using the relative crank length of your old bikes with the new gear-inches and new crank length. Use it as a multiplying ratio. Frame size does not enter into it if you are fitted properly using your seat/knee height angles.
